meta.title: The Ten Commandments of A-List Copywriters: Control-Beating Breakthroughs From Gary Bencivenga, Gene Schwartz, Jim Rutz & More
meta.author: John Bejakovic

parts.title: Secrets of A-List Copywriting Summarized
parts.body: A-list copywriters are like Hollywood stars, but instead of acting, they transform products into blockbusters with their words, staying successful for decades. This book delves into key "commandments" or secrets from these top-notch copywriters, teaching techniques and career principles that can improve sales letters and enhance careers. The first commandment highlights the importance of proof in advertising, above flashy promises, to combat reader skepticism, with insights from legendary copywriters like Gary Bencivenga, who used concrete examples and results as solid evidence within ads.

parts.title: Building Belief Through Gradualization
parts.body: Gene's ad for repairing TVs didn't start with telling people how easy it is to fix or how much money they could save. Instead, it began with an intriguing headline: "Why Haven't TV Owners Been Told These Facts?". It systematically introduced the idea of easily fixing a TV by twisting knobs, laying the groundwork for the reader to eventually accept they could do it too. This illustrates gradualization, building credibility by sequencing claims logically to increase belief in each step. Similarly, in Parris Lampropoulos’s ad, the process moved from the fact that doctors seldom wash hands, to using herbs and remedies for personal wellness. This indirectly built trust by starting with reliable facts the audience would find surprising and believable, leading them to consider other bolder claims. The technique shows how preparing the reader with carefully arranged facts enhances persuasion.
